problem_statement: Derive the parametric vector equation of the plane passing through three given non-collinear points A, B, C whose position vectors with respect to the origin are \(\vec a, \vec b, \vec c\). Express the position vector \(\vec r\) of an arbitrary point P on this plane in terms of real parameters.
overview: Use the fact that two non-parallel direction vectors lying in a plane span that plane. Vectors \(\vec{AB}=\vec b-\vec a\) and \(\vec{AC}=\vec c-\vec a\) are non-zero and non-collinear, so any vector from A to a point P on the plane can be written as a linear combination of these two.

step_details.explanation: Name the data and record the non-collinearity condition.
expressions: $\text{Given } A(\vec a),\ B(\vec b),\ C(\vec c)\ \text{ are non-collinear.}$
$\Rightarrow\ (\vec b-\vec a)\times(\vec c-\vec a)\neq\vec 0 \quad \color{blue}{\text{(directions not parallel)}}$

step_details.explanation: Pick an arbitrary point P on the plane and relate its position vector to A.
expressions: $P \text{ lies on plane } \Rightarrow \vec{AP} \text{ lies in the plane through } A,$
$\vec r \text{ is the position vector of } P \Rightarrow \vec{AP}=\vec r-\vec a.$

step_details.explanation: Because \(\vec{AB}\) and \(\vec{AC}\) span the plane, write \(\vec{AP}\) as their linear combination.
expressions: $\Rightarrow\ \vec r-\vec a=s(\vec b-\vec a)+t(\vec c-\vec a).$
$\Rightarrow\ \vec r=\vec a+s(\vec b-\vec a)+t(\vec c-\vec a).$
$\text{Here } s,t\in\mathbb{R},\ (\vec b-\vec a)\times(\vec c-\vec a)\neq\vec 0 \quad \color{blue}{\text{(two independent directions)}}$

step_details.explanation: State the final parametric vector equation of the plane through A, B, C.
expressions: $\boxed{\vec r=\vec a+s(\vec b-\vec a)+t(\vec c-\vec a),\quad s,t\in\mathbb{R}}\quad \color{blue}{\text{(parametric form of the plane)}}$
